text.div:
NameFlagsCard.TypeDescription & Constraints
Conformance 1..1
rest S0..*BackboneElement
security S0..1BackboneElement
extension-dstu2-oauth-uris S1..1(Complex)Support for dicovery of OAuth2 endpoints
URL: http://hl7.org/fhir/DSTU2/smart-app-launch/StructureDefinition/extension-dstu2-oauth-uris

Documentation for this format

name: SMART on FHIR Conformance
publisher: Boston's Children Hospital and Hl7 International
description: The SMART on FHIR Â Conformance defines extensions  for automated discovery of OAuth2 endpoints and optional SMART launch features.   These extensions  are  marked as "Must Support"  whihc  means servers SHALL include the extensions as part of their Conformance if the data is present or feature is supported and clients SHALL  be capable of processing a CapabiltyStatement instances containing the data elements without generating an error an causing the application to fail.

element.name: Conformance
element.definition: This is a simple example Template.

constraint.human: Conformance statements of kind 'requirements' do not have software or implementation elements
A Conformance statement SHALL have at least one of REST, messaging or document
Conformance statements of kind 'software' do not have implementation elements
A Conformance statement SHALL have at least one of description, software, or implementation
Messaging end-point is required (and is only permitted) when statement is for an implementation
The set of documents must be unique by the combination of profile & mode
There can only be one REST declaration per mode

element.name: Conformance.id
element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comments: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation. Bundles always have an id, though it is usually a generated UUID.

element.name: Conformance.meta
element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content may not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

element.name: Conformance.implicitRules
element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content.
element.comments: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element as much as possible.

element.name: Conformance.language
element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comments: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource  Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

binding.description: A human language.

element.name: Conformance.text
element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comments: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative.

element.name: Conformance.contained
element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comments: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.

element.name: Conformance.extension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Conformance.modifierExtension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Conformance.url
element.short: Logical uri to reference this statement
element.definition: An absolute URL that is used to identify this conformance statement when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance. This SHALL be a URL, SHOULD be globally unique, and SHOULD be an address at which this conformance statement is (or will be) published.

element.name: Conformance.version
element.short: Logical id for this version of the statement
element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the conformance statement when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the profile author manually and the value should be a timestamp.
element.comments: There may be multiple different instances of a conformance statement that have the same identifier but different versions.

element.name: Conformance.name
element.short: Informal name for this conformance statement
element.definition: A free text natural language name identifying the conformance statement.
element.comments: The name is not expected to be globally unique.

element.name: Conformance.status
element.definition: The status of this conformance statement.
element.comments: This is not intended for use with actual conformance statements, but where conformance statements are used to describe possible or desired systems.

binding.description: The lifecycle status of a Value Set or Concept Map.

element.name: Conformance.experimental
element.short: If for testing purposes, not real usage
element.definition: A flag to indicate that this conformance statement is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing), and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.comments: Allows filtering of conformance statements that are appropriate for use vs. not.

element.name: Conformance.publisher
element.short: Name of the publisher (Organization or individual)
element.definition: The name of the individual or organization that published the conformance.
element.comments: Usually an organization, but may be an individual. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the conformance.  May also allow for contact.

element.name: Conformance.contact
element.definition: Contacts to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
element.comments: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number (tel:), etc.

element.name: Conformance.contact.id
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.name: Conformance.contact.extension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Conformance.contact.modifierExtension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Conformance.contact.name
element.short: Name of a individual to contact
element.definition: The name of an individual to contact regarding the conformance.
element.comments: If there is no named individual, the telecom is for the organization as a whole.

element.name: Conformance.contact.telecom
element.short: Contact details for individual or publisher
element.definition: Contact details for individual (if a name was provided) or the publisher.

element.name: Conformance.date
element.definition: The date  (and optionally time) when the conformance statement was published. The date must change when the business version changes, if it does, and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the conformance statement changes.
element.comments: Additional specific dates may be added as extensions.

element.name: Conformance.description
element.short: Human description of the conformance statement
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the conformance statement and its use. Typically, this is used when the conformance statement describes a desired rather than an actual solution, for example as a formal expression of requirements as part of an RFP.
element.comments: This field may include the purpose of this conformance statement, comments about its context etc. This does not need to be populated if the description is adequately implied by the software or implementation details.

element.name: Conformance.requirements
element.definition: Explains why this conformance statement is needed and why it's been constrained as it has.
element.comments: This element does not describe the usage of the conformance statement (that's done in comments), rather it's for traceability of *why* the element is either needed or why the constraints exist as they do.  This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this data element.

element.name: Conformance.copyright
element.definition: A copyright statement relating to the conformance statement and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the details of the system described by the conformance statement.

element.name: Conformance.kind
element.definition: The way that this statement is intended to be used, to describe an actual running instance of software, a particular product (kind not instance of software) or a class of implementation (e.g. a desired purchase).

binding.description: How a conformance statement is intended to be used.

element.name: Conformance.software
element.short: Software that is covered by this conformance statement
element.definition: Software that is covered by this conformance statement.  It is used when the conformance statement describes the capabilities of a particular software version, independent of an installation.

element.name: Conformance.software.id
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.name: Conformance.software.extension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Conformance.software.modifierExtension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Conformance.software.name
element.short: A name the software is known by
element.definition: Name software is known by.

element.name: Conformance.software.version
element.definition: The version identifier for the software covered by this statement.
element.comments: If possible, version should be specified, as statements are likely to be different for different versions of software.

element.name: Conformance.software.releaseDate
element.definition: Date this version of the software released.

element.name: Conformance.implementation
element.short: If this describes a specific instance
element.definition: Identifies a specific implementation instance that is described by the conformance statement - i.e. a particular installation, rather than the capabilities of a software program.

element.name: Conformance.implementation.id
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.name: Conformance.implementation.extension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Conformance.implementation.modifierExtension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Conformance.implementation.description
element.definition: Information about the specific installation that this conformance statement relates to.

element.name: Conformance.implementation.url
element.definition: An absolute base URL for the implementation.  This forms the base for REST interfaces as well as the mailbox and document interfaces.

element.name: Conformance.fhirVersion
element.definition: The version of the FHIR specification on which this conformance statement is based.

element.name: Conformance.acceptUnknown
element.definition: A code that indicates whether the application accepts unknown elements or extensions when reading resources.
element.comments: Unknown elements in a resource can only arise as later versions of the specification are published, because this is the only place where such elements can be defined. Hence accepting unknown elements is about inter-version compatibility.  Applications are recommended to accept unknown extensions and elements ('both'), but this is not always possible.

binding.description: A code that indicates whether an application accepts unknown elements or extensions when reading resources.

element.name: Conformance.format
element.definition: A list of the formats supported by this implementation using their content types.
element.comments: "xml" or "json" are allowed, which describe the simple encodings described in the specification (and imply appropriate bundle support). Otherwise, mime types are legal here.

binding.description: The mime type of an attachment. Any valid mime type is allowed.

element.name: Conformance.profile
element.definition: A list of profiles that represent different use cases supported by the system. For a server, "supported by the system" means the system hosts/produces a set of resources that are conformant to a particular profile, and allows clients that use its services to search using this profile and to find appropriate data. For a client, it means the system will search by this profile and process data according to the guidance implicit in the profile. See further discussion in [Using Profiles]{profiling.html#profile-uses}.
element.comments: Supported profiles are different to the profiles that apply to a particular resource in rest.resource.profile. The resource profile is a general statement of what features of the resource are supported overall by the system - the sum total of the facilities it supports. A supported profile is a deeper statement about the functionality of the data and services provided by the server (or used by the client). A typical case is a laboratory system that produces a set of different reports - this is the list of types of data that it publishes. A key aspect of declaring profiles here is the question of how the client converts knowledge that the server publishes this data into working with the data; the client can inspect individual resources to determine whether they conform to a particular profile, but how does it find the ones that does? It does so by searching using the _profile parameter, so any resources listed here must be valid values for the _profile resource (using the identifier in the target profile).  Typical supported profiles cross resource types to describe a network of related resources, so they are listed here rather than by resource. However, they do not need to describe more than one resource.

element.name: Conformance.rest
element.short: If the endpoint is a RESTful one
element.definition: A definition of the restful capabilities of the solution, if any.
element.comments: Multiple repetitions allow definition of both client and / or server behaviors or possibly behaviors under different configuration settings (for software or requirements statements).

constraint.human: A given resource can only be described once per RESTful mode

element.name: Conformance.rest.id
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.name: Conformance.rest.extension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Conformance.rest.modifierExtension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Conformance.rest.mode
element.definition: Identifies whether this portion of the statement is describing ability to initiate or receive restful operations.

binding.description: The mode of a RESTful conformance statement.

element.name: Conformance.rest.documentation
element.definition: Information about the system's restful capabilities that apply across all applications, such as security.

element.name: Conformance.rest.security
element.definition: Information about security implementation from an interface perspective - what a client needs to know.

element.name: Conformance.rest.security.id
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.name: Conformance.rest.security.extension
element.definition: An Extension

element.name: oauth-uris
element.short: Support for dicovery of OAuth2 endpoints
element.definition: An Extension

element.name: Conformance.rest.security.modifierExtension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Conformance.rest.security.cors
element.definition: Server adds CORS headers when responding to requests - this enables javascript applications to use the server.
element.comments: The easiest CORS headers to add are Access-Control-Allow-Origin: * & Access-Control-Request-Method: GET, POST, PUT, DELETE. All servers SHOULD support CORS.

element.name: Conformance.rest.security.service
element.short: OAuth | SMART-on-FHIR | NTLM | Basic | Kerberos | Certificates
element.definition: Types of security services are supported/required by the system.

binding.description: Types of security services used with FHIR.

element.name: Conformance.rest.security.description
element.short: General description of how security works
element.definition: General description of how security works.

element.name: Conformance.rest.security.certificate
element.definition: Certificates associated with security profiles.

element.name: Conformance.rest.security.certificate.id
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.name: Conformance.rest.security.certificate.extension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Conformance.rest.security.certificate.type
element.definition: Mime type for certificate.

binding.description: The mime type of an attachment. Any valid mime type is allowed.

element.name: Conformance.rest.security.certificate.blob
element.definition: Actual certificate.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource
element.short: Resource served on the REST interface
element.definition: A specification of the restful capabilities of the solution for a specific resource type.
element.comments: Max of one repetition per resource type.

constraint.human: Search parameter names must be unique in the context of a resource

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.id
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.extension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.modifierExtension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.type
element.short: A resource type that is supported
element.definition: A type of resource exposed via the restful interface.

binding.description: One of the resource types defined as part of FHIR.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.profile
element.short: Base System profile for all uses of resource
element.definition: A specification of the profile that describes the solution's overall support for the resource, including any constraints on cardinality, bindings, lengths or other limitations. See further discussion in [Using Profiles]{profiling.html#profile-uses}.
element.comments: The profile applies to all  resources of this type - i.e. it is the superset of what is supported by the system.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.interaction
element.definition: Identifies a restful operation supported by the solution.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.interaction.id
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.interaction.extension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.interaction.modifierExtension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.interaction.code
element.short: read | vread | update | delete | history-instance | validate | history-type | create | search-type
element.definition: Coded identifier of the operation, supported by the system resource.

binding.description: Operations supported by REST at the type or instance level.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.interaction.documentation
element.definition: Guidance specific to the implementation of this operation, such as 'delete is a logical delete' or 'updates are only allowed with version id' or 'creates permitted from pre-authorized certificates only'.
element.requirements: REST allows a degree of variability in the implementation of RESTful solutions that is useful for exchange partners to be aware of.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.versioning
element.definition: This field is set to no-version to specify that the system does not support (server) or use (client) versioning for this resource type. If this has some other value, the server must at least correctly track and populate the versionId meta-property on resources. If the value is 'versioned-update', then the server supports all the versioning features, including using e-tags for version integrity in the API.
element.comments: If a server supports versionIds correctly, it SHOULD support vread too, but is not required to do so.

binding.description: How the system supports versioning for a resource.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.readHistory
element.short: Whether vRead can return past versions
element.definition: A flag for whether the server is able to return past versions as part of the vRead operation.
element.comments: It is useful to support the vRead operation for current operations, even if past versions aren't available.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.updateCreate
element.short: If update can commit to a new identity
element.definition: A flag to indicate that the server allows or needs to allow the client to create new identities on the server (e.g. that is, the client PUTs to a location where there is no existing resource). Allowing this operation means that the server allows the client to create new identities on the server.
element.comments: Allowing the clients to create new identities on the server means that the system administrator needs to have confidence that the clients do not create clashing identities between them. Obviously, if there is only one client, this won't happen. While creating identities on the client means that the clients need to be managed, it's much more convenient for many scenarios if such management can be put in place.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.conditionalCreate
element.definition: A flag that indicates that the server supports conditional create.
element.comments: Conditional Create is mainly appropriate for interface engine scripts converting from other formats, such as v2.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.conditionalUpdate
element.definition: A flag that indicates that the server supports conditional update.
element.comments: Conditional Update is mainly appropriate for interface engine scripts converting from other formats, such as v2.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.conditionalDelete
element.short: not-supported | single | multiple - how conditional delete is supported
element.definition: A code that indicates how the server supports conditional delete.
element.comments: Conditional Delete is mainly appropriate for interface engine scripts converting from other formats, such as v2.

binding.description: A code that indicates how the server supports conditional delete.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.searchInclude
element.definition: A list of _include values supported by the server.
element.comments: If this list is empty, the server does not support includes.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.searchRevInclude
element.definition: A list of _revinclude (reverse include) values supported by the server.
element.comments: If this list is empty, the server does not support includes.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.searchParam
element.definition: Search parameters for implementations to support and/or make use of - either references to ones defined in the specification, or additional ones defined for/by the implementation.

constraint.human: Search parameters can only have chain names when the search parameter type is 'reference'

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.searchParam.id
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.searchParam.extension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.searchParam.modifierExtension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.searchParam.name
element.definition: The name of the search parameter used in the interface.
element.comments: Parameter names cannot overlap with standard parameter names, and standard parameters cannot be redefined.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.searchParam.definition
element.definition: An absolute URI that is a formal reference to where this parameter was first defined, so that a client can be confident of the meaning of the search parameter (a reference to [[[SearchParameter.url]]]).
element.comments: This SHOULD be present, and matches SearchParameter.url.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.searchParam.type
element.short: number | date | string | token | reference | composite | quantity | uri
element.definition: The type of value a search parameter refers to, and how the content is interpreted.
element.comments: While this can be looked up from the definition, it is included here as a convenience for systems that autogenerate a query interface based on the server conformance statement.  It SHALL be the same as the type in the search parameter definition.

binding.description: Data types allowed to be used for search parameters.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.searchParam.documentation
element.definition: This allows documentation of any distinct behaviors about how the search parameter is used.  For example, text matching algorithms.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.searchParam.target
element.short: Types of resource (if a resource reference)
element.definition: Types of resource (if a resource is referenced).
element.comments: This SHALL be the same as or a proper subset of the resources listed in the search parameter definition.

binding.description: One of the resource types defined as part of FHIR.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.searchParam.modifier
element.short: missing | exact | contains | not | text | in | not-in | below | above | type
element.definition: A modifier supported for the search parameter.

binding.description: A supported modifier for a search parameter.

element.name: Conformance.rest.resource.searchParam.chain
element.definition: Contains the names of any search parameters which may be chained to the containing search parameter. Chained parameters may be added to search parameters of type reference, and specify that resources will only be returned if they contain a reference to a resource which matches the chained parameter value. Values for this field should be drawn from Conformance.rest.resource.searchParam.name on the target resource type.
element.comments: Systems are not required to list all the chain names they support, but if they don't list them, clients may not know to use them.

element.name: Conformance.rest.interaction
element.definition: A specification of restful operations supported by the system.

element.name: Conformance.rest.interaction.id
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.name: Conformance.rest.interaction.extension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Conformance.rest.interaction.modifierExtension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. element.name: Conformance.rest.interaction.code
element.definition: A coded identifier of the operation, supported by the system.

binding.description: Operations supported by REST at the system level.

element.name: Conformance.rest.interaction.documentation
element.definition: Guidance specific to the implementation of this operation, such as limitations on the kind of transactions allowed, or information about system wide search is implemented.

element.name: Conformance.rest.transactionMode
element.definition: A code that indicates how transactions are supported.

binding.description: A code that indicates how transactions are supported.

element.name: Conformance.rest.searchParam
element.short: Search params for searching all resources
element.definition: Search parameters that are supported for searching all resources for implementations to support and/or make use of - either references to ones defined in the specification, or additional ones defined for/by the implementation.
element.comments: Typically, the only search parameters supported for all parameters are search parameters that apply to all resources - tags, profiles, text search etc.

element.name: Conformance.rest.operation
element.short: Definition of an operation or a custom query
element.definition: Definition of an operation or a named query and with its parameters and their meaning and type.

element.name: Conformance.rest.operation.id
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.name: Conformance.rest.operation.extension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Conformance.rest.operation.modifierExtension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Conformance.rest.operation.name
element.short: Name by which the operation/query is invoked
element.definition: The name of a query, which is used in the _query parameter when the query is called.
element.comments: The name here SHOULD be the same as the name in the definition, unless there is a name clash and the name cannot be used.

element.name: Conformance.rest.operation.definition
element.definition: Where the formal definition can be found.
element.comments: This can be used to build an HTML form to invoke the operation, for instance.

element.name: Conformance.rest.compartment
element.definition: An absolute URI which is a reference to the definition of a compartment hosted by the system.
element.comments: At present, the only defined compartments are at [[compartments.html]].

element.name: Conformance.messaging
element.definition: A description of the messaging capabilities of the solution.
element.comments: Multiple repetitions allow the documentation of multiple endpoints per solution.

element.name: Conformance.messaging.id
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.name: Conformance.messaging.extension

element.name: Conformance.messaging.endpoint
element.definition: An endpoint (network accessible address) to which messages and/or replies are to be sent.

element.name: Conformance.messaging.endpoint.id
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.name: Conformance.messaging.endpoint.extension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. element.name: Conformance.messaging.endpoint.protocol
element.definition: A list of the messaging transport protocol(s) identifiers, supported by this endpoint.

binding.description: The protocol used for message transport.

element.name: Conformance.messaging.endpoint.address
element.definition: The network address of the end-point. For solutions that do not use network addresses for routing, it can be just an identifier.

element.name: Conformance.messaging.reliableCache
element.definition: Length if the receiver's reliable messaging cache in minutes (if a receiver) or how long the cache length on the receiver should be (if a sender).
element.comments: If this value is missing then the application does not implement (receiver) or depend on (sender) reliable messaging.

element.name: Conformance.messaging.documentation
element.definition: Documentation about the system's messaging capabilities for this endpoint not otherwise documented by the conformance statement.  For example, process for becoming an authorized messaging exchange partner.

element.name: Conformance.messaging.event
element.definition: A description of the solution's support for an event at this end-point.
element.comments: The same event may be listed up to two times - once as sender and once as receiver.

element.name: Conformance.messaging.event.id
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.name: Conformance.messaging.event.extension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. element.name: Conformance.messaging.event.code
element.definition: A coded identifier of a supported messaging event.

binding.description: One of the message events defined as part of FHIR.

element.name: Conformance.messaging.event.category
element.definition: The impact of the content of the message.

binding.description: The impact of the content of a message.

element.name: Conformance.messaging.event.mode
element.definition: The mode of this event declaration - whether application is sender or receiver.

binding.description: The mode of a message conformance statement.

element.name: Conformance.messaging.event.focus
element.definition: A resource associated with the event.  This is the resource that defines the event.
element.comments: This SHALL be provided if the event type supports multiple different resource types.

binding.description: One of the resource types defined as part of FHIR.

element.name: Conformance.messaging.event.request
element.definition: Information about the request for this event.

element.name: Conformance.messaging.event.response
element.definition: Information about the response for this event.

element.name: Conformance.messaging.event.documentation
element.definition: Guidance on how this event is handled, such as internal system trigger points, business rules, etc.

element.definition: A document definition.

element.name: Conformance.document.mode
element.definition: Mode of this document declaration - whether application is producer or consumer.

binding.description: Whether the application produces or consumes documents.

element.name: Conformance.document.documentation
element.definition: A description of how the application supports or uses the specified document profile.  For example, when are documents created, what action is taken with consumed documents, etc.

element.name: Conformance.document.profile
element.short: Constraint on a resource used in the document
element.definition: A constraint on a resource used in the document.
element.comments: The first resource is the document resource.

element.name: Conformance
element.definition: This is a simple example Template.

element.name: oauth-uris
element.short: Support for dicovery of OAuth2 endpoints
